*The Supplementary Commentaries on the "True Classic of Southern Florescence"*

**Author:** Chen Jingyuan of the Northern Song Dynasty
**Volume:** One
**Source Text:** *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Cavern Spirit Division, Jade Instructions Category

---

**Supplementary Commentaries on the "True Classic of Southern Florescence"**
*By Master Bi Xu*

**Lacunae and Errors**

**Free and Easy Wandering**
*"It is also like this, and nothing more."*
—Seen in the *Wenruo Hai* edition; formerly rendered as *"then."*

*"Halting at the catalpa or mulberry"*
—Seen in the *Wen* edition and *Jiangnan* edition; formerly lacunate.

*"His belly still bulging"*
—Seen in the *Wen* edition; formerly rendered as *"fruit."*

*"What do those two insects know?"*
—Seen in the *Wen* edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Eight thousand years as one autumn—this is great longevity."*
—Seen in Cheng Yuanying’s edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Is it only the body that may be deaf and blind?"*
—Seen in the ancient manuscript of Fangying Abbey on Tiantai Mountain; formerly rendered as *"blind."*

*"I beg to buy his recipe for a hundred gold pieces."*
—Seen in the ancient *Jiangnan* manuscript; formerly lacunate.

*"Where would there be any distress or suffering?"*
—Text reads *"Where would there be any exhaustion or suffering?"*

*Above: Thirteen characters*

**Discussion on Making All Things Equal**
*"Old man Xu"*
—*Jiangnan* ancient manuscript reads *"overflows."*

*"Though I too have become"*
—*Jiangnan* ancient manuscript reads *"Though I have no achievement, it may also be called achievement."*

*"Benevolence is constant yet not all-encompassing"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"achievement."*

*"Whirlwinds stir the sea"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* Li family edition; formerly lacunate.

*"The sage is foolish and dull"*
—Seen in Liu Deyi’s edition; formerly rendered as *"tun."*

*"Then is this different from ‘is not’? There would be no distinction."*
*"If it is truly so, then is ‘so’ different from ‘not so’? There would also be no distinction."*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript.

*Above: Twelve characters*

**Nurturing the Life-Force**

*"The ox knows not its death—*
*like earth returning to earth."*
—Seen in the *Wen Ruhai* and Liu Deyi editions; formerly lacunate.

*"At first, I took them for perfected beings"*
—Seen in the *Wen* edition; formerly rendered as *"its."*

*Above: Seven characters*

**The Human World**

*"Pondering one’s path may yet suffice"*
—Seen in the Li family edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Alas! Should you go, peril and punishment await"*
—Seen in Zhang Junfang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"Should peril go, punishment awaits."*

*"Those who flaunt themselves before the violent"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"art."*

*"To act with intent—how could it be easy?"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Few fail to act contrary to the Way yet still achieve joy"*
—*Jiangnan* ancient manuscript reads *"Few possess the Way yet still achieve joy."*

*"Its great harm spans thousands of oxen"*
—Text identical in the *Wen*, *Li*, and *Zhang* editions; formerly lacunate.

*"To conceal and shelter what one relies upon"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"Concealing, I will."*

*"Withdraw, withdraw"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"My path withdraws."*

*Above: Twenty characters*

**Virtue’s Full Manifestation**

*"Those who guard their root"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly lacunate.

*"Receiving their mandate from earth,*
*only the pine and cypress stand alone—*
*evergreen through winter and summer.*

*Receiving their mandate from heaven,*
*only Yao and Shun stand alone—*
*supreme among the ten thousand things."*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Does your virtue truly suffice for self-reflection?"*
—*Wen*, *Li*, and *Zhang* editions concur; formerly rendered as *"Does it not suffice for self-reflection?"*

*"Do I not know whether the master washes me with goodness,*
*or whether I awaken myself?"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly lacunate.

*"Was Confucius ever thus with the perfected?"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"Was it not thus?"*

*Above: Fourteen characters*

**The Great Ancestral Master**

*"Ah! How joyous he seems!*
*How towering! How compelled!*
*How stern! How worldly!"*

—*Wen* and *Zhang* editions read:
*"Ah! How joyous he seems!*
*How towering, how compelled!*
*How stern, how worldly!"*

*"Goodness is rare"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"premature."*

*"Thus, those who kill life do not die"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly lacunate.

*"To go and serve him"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"await."*

*Above: Seven characters*

**Responding to Emperors and Kings**

*"Which commoner would dare not heed and be transformed?"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"to measure others."*

*"I and you have no such text"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"already."*

*"Neither shaken nor stilled"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"rectified."*

*"Chaotically, they enfeoff!"*
—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly lacunate.
*Above: Five characters*

**Joined Toes**

*"Yet many diverge in the use of hearing and sight"*
—Zhang’s edition reads: *"Yet many [ ] in the use of hearing and sight."*

*"Those with branched limbs do not count as forked"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"striving."*

*Above: Two characters*

**Horse [ ]**

*"[ ] bridles them"*
—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"luò."*

*Above: One character*

**Prying Open Chests**

*How could they not model themselves on the sagely and wise?*
*The good cannot stand without the Way of the sagely and wise;*
*Zhí cannot act without the Way of the sagely and wise—*
*Thus, the sagely and wise benefit the world but little.*

*When sagely wisdom arises, great thieves appear;*
*Smash and strike at sagely wisdom—once sagely wisdom is dead,*
*Even if sagely wisdom is doubled, this is but the fault of sagely wisdom.*
*Those sagely and wise are the world’s sharpest tools.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"people."*
*Above: Eleven characters*

**Chiseling Intent**

Therefore it is said: *"The sage rests therein—*
*resting, all becomes level and easy."*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"The sage rests and rests therein—then all becomes early and easy."*
*Above: One character*

**Mending Nature**

*Mending nature through custom:*
*customary learning seeks to restore its origin.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"Mending nature through custom—customary learning seeks to restore its origin."*
*Cultivating desire amid desire:*
*thought strives to attain its clarity.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"custom."*

*Those who governed by the Way in ancient times*
*nurtured wisdom with tranquility;*
*wisdom arose yet they did not employ it as wisdom—*
*this is called "nurturing tranquility with wisdom."*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"omitted."*
*Righteousness was luminous and things drew near in loyalty.*

—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; rendered as *"center."*
*Rites and music spread universally.*

—Seen in the *Jiangnan* ancient manuscript; rendered as *"partial."*
*The four seasons responded in season.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"attained."*
*What more was there to do?*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"omitted."*
*Cap and chariot upon the body—*
*these were not of one’s nature and destiny.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"omitted."*
*Above: Nine characters*

**Discourse on the Sword**

*How could Kuǐ dare speak?*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"still."*
*Above: One character*

**The Old Fisherman**

*Radiant whiteness.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"mingled."*
*Standing in the leeward.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"awaiting."*
*To corrupt the virtuous.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"the wicked,"* pronounced *wū-lù.*
*Above: Three characters*

**The King of Chan**

Lest hearing be misconstrued—seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"lest the hearer be misled."*
*Singing to the zither.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
*Not to burden oneself with envy.*

—Seen in Master Li’s edition; formerly rendered as *"profit."*
*The spirit harbors no aversion.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"how."*
*Thus do I know the flourishing of the pine and cypress:*
*Duke Huan found it in Ju—when chaos reigned in Qi and Xiaobai fled to Ju.*
*Duke Wen found it in Cao—when the people of Cao beheld the ribs of the Prince of Jin.*
*The King of Yue found it at Kuaiji—when Yue was crushed by Wu and Goujian, defeated, took refuge upon Mount Kuaiji.*

—From *"Duke Huan found it in Ju"* to *"took refuge upon Mount Kuaiji,"* forty-eight characters—seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.
*Thus Xu You found peace in Yingyang, and Gongbo realized his ambition upon the mound—"peace" meaning tranquility.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"misguided ambition,"* formerly omitted.
*The virtue of Yin declined.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"Zhou."*
*Above: Fifty-five characters*

**Robber Zhi**
*Hollowed chambers and gouged doors.*

—Seen in Liu Deyi’s edition; formerly rendered as *"pivot."*
*Resting his troops on the southern slopes of Mount Tai.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.
*All under heaven possess three virtues.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
*These seven masters are those whom the world exalts.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"six."*
*These six masters differ not from dismembered dogs or drifting swine.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"four."*
*Those who clutch gourds and beg all prize fame and scorn death.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"detached."*
*If you conduct yourself like Jie or Zhou, those who flush with anger and show disdain will arise.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"then will show displeasure."*
*Long ago, I debated with you before Wu Yue, saying:*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"saying."*
*It is like one afflicted by evening sickness, enduring prolonged distress.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.
*Like bearing a heavy load while ascending a slope.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
*Greed for wealth brings humiliation.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"comfort."*
*Above: Eleven characters*

**In the Realm of Pervasive Indulgence**
*Mount Kongtong.*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"above."*
*By this means, one relies on another’s state for good fortune.*

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.
*Above: Two characters*

**Heaven and Earth**

Thus, that which aligns with Heaven is the Dao; that which accords with Earth is virtue. That which operates through the myriad things is righteousness.

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted; the first five characters were formerly rendered with *Dao* in place of *righteousness*.

A pearl submerged in the abyss.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"hidden."*

To yield oneself.

—*Ji* (紀), seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *si* (巳).

Here stands a device—its name is the well-sweep.

—*Ji* (机) and *jiegao* (桔槔) seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted; *jie* (桔) formerly rendered as *zuo* (作).

What the sage feels shame for.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"the sage feels shame for it."*

No mutual imputation of guilt.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
Above: Thirteen characters

**The Dao of Heaven**
Its spontaneity is its action.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

And the ultimate of Dao and virtue.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

In truth, it is order.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"in truth, it is complete."*

Names and forms are compared and examined.

—*Xiang* (详) seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *xing* (刑) below as well.

How wondrously divine are Heaven and Earth!

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

How could they require the Dao?

—Seen in the Wen edition; formerly omitted.

This is not the Dao of one who knows governance.

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

Abysmally unfathomable!

—Seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.
Above: Nine characters

**The Revolution of Heaven**

Who exalts and who bestows?—Li’s edition reads *shi* (弛).

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"there is."*

Names are the public instruments.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

Why then so fiercely imposing?

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

I open my mouth yet cannot restrain my tongue; I raise it yet cannot begin.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

Thus the perfected one

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

moves as Heaven and Earth do!

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"does he?"*

The governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors.

Of old, the Yellow Emperor’s rule over the world

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

his gaze unmoving yet stirring transformation by wind, the feminine responding to the wind below—thus it was called *"wind transformation."*

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
Above: Seventeen characters
**Autumn Floods**

The Five Emperors’ revolutions

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"linked."*

are but different conveniences.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

Thus the great person’s conduct never treads the path of harming others.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

Is this called usurpation?

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

To know human conduct

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"Heaven’s."*

yet not meet the times

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"obtain."*

in the age of Yao and Shun, in the age of Jie and Zhou

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

leaping beyond the well’s railing

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"leaping wildly."*

Moreover, you say:

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
Above: Fourteen characters
**Utmost Joy**

I know not whether this is joy, nor whether it is not joy—is there truly joy or is there none? Yet I find joy in the sincerity of non-action.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

All things transform and arise.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

Now they change and die.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"Now they change again and turn to death."*

The skull appeared in a dream and said: "In your discourse..."

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.

...you drift with heaven and earth as the seasons.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"follow."*

Why then return to the toils of the living?

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"the labors of the human realm?"*

They must differ in their likes and dislikes—for likes and dislikes differ, and thus the sages of old did not unify their abilities.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"thus they differed."*

Species have their limits: if Yi became a quail...

—From Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly omitted.

Si Mi ate vinegar, vinegar arose from Yi Lu, Yi Lu from Huang Yue, Huang Yue from Jiu You, Jiu You from Mao Rui, Mao Rui from rotten grubs, rotten grubs from Yang Xi, Yang Xi paired with the un-sprouting bamboo, and old bamboo gave birth to Qing Ning.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.
Above: Thirty-eight characters
**Attaining Life**

It is but form and appearance.

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

How could things correct it?

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"stop."*

Do not open the human within the human.

—From Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly rendered as *"heaven."*

With tiles as spoons, hooks as spoons, gold as spoons.

—From the *Lüshi Chunqiu*; formerly rendered as *"annotation."*

There was a man named Zhang Yi...

—From the *Records of High Gates and County Registers*; from Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly omitted.

What people most fear...

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"seek."*

I shall nourish you for three months.

—Seen in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *""*, not included in the rhyme scheme of the chapter.

If you scheme for yourself, why take what differs from a pig?

—From Zhang Qianfu’s edition; formerly omitted.

A different rooster—none dare respond, and they flee instead.

—Text as in Hai Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly omitted.

Is it because of this?

—From the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

The mouth forgets right and wrong.

—Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"knowing forgets right and wrong."*

Then there is only peace upon the level land.

—From Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly omitted.
Above: Fourteen characters
**Mountain Trees**

The efflux of transformation and change—seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"things."*

Hitching up one’s robes and striding swiftly—from Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"hitching."*

Zhuangzi returned to his palace and for three months did not appear in the courtyard—seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

Following his command—text as in the Jiangnan Li family’s Cheng edition; formerly rendered as *"custom."*

[...] the gamekeeper, taking me for one to be executed—text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"the gamekeeper of the chestnut grove."*

The innkeeper had two concubines—from Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly rendered as *"people."*

Above: seven characters
**Tian Zifang**

His guidance to me was like a father’s—seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"the Way."*

Above: one character
**Knowing Northward**

*Know* as written; formerly pronounced *zhi* (wisdom), not adopted.

Thus it is said: It is the one qi that pervades Heaven and Earth—from Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly rendered as *"the one qi that pervades all under Heaven."*

Unite with that spirit-light and utmost essence—from Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly rendered as *"command."*

Children and grandchildren are not yours—from Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"grandchildren."*

Measuring and sustaining the ten thousand things without omission—text as in Liu’s edition; formerly rendered as *"without want."*

You must not insist that nothing can escape things—text as in Zhang Cheng’s edition; formerly omitted.

Mountains and forests, marshlands and wilds—none are kin to me, yet they make me joyful and glad—seen in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.

Above: eleven characters (the character *zhi* excluded)
**Gengsang Chu**

The words are exhausted—yet the rushing bee cannot transform the mallow’s flame. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition and Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"it is said, the rushing bee cannot transform the mallow’s flame."*)

Ten days to still sorrow. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition, Liu’s edition, and Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"from itself."*)

People see their *ren* and *wu*—they see their *wu*. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Every delusion compounds the loss. (Text as in Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly omitted.)

Emerging and entering yet never revealing its form. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"entering and emerging."*)

Who knows the one source of being and non-being, death and life? (Text as in the Wen edition; formerly rendered as *"guard."*)

Then it suits its slumber and piss. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition and Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Shifting right and wrong—these are the people of today. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition and Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Above: twelve characters

**Xu Wugui**

The path of *li* and *huo*, pillars and eaves, weasels and ferrets. (Text as in the Wen and Zhang editions; formerly rendered as *"in"* or *"of."*)

The discerning scholar finds no joy without the reproach of towering words. (Text as in the Wen and Cheng Zhang editions; formerly rendered as *"the affairs of towering reproach."*)

Listen and carve it—eyes shut, hands unrestrained, plastering all with whitewash while the nose remains unharmed. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition; the last four characters formerly attributed to Guo’s commentary.)

Can one not speak of it? (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition; formerly rendered as *"it is said."*)

Wandering through Heaven and Earth. (Text as in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly omitted.)

Choosing sparse fur and long hair, they deem it a vast palace and great park. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

The true person of old used Heaven to await humanity. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"of."*)

Above: twelve characters

**Ze Yang**

Bathing within the same pen. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"overflowing."*)

The most expansive of qi. (Text as in Liu’s *De Yi* edition; formerly rendered as *"great."*)

Above: two characters

**External Things**

I shall journey south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Gathering firewood. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

The conduct of the common people is easily advanced. (Text as in Zhang Cheng’s edition; formerly omitted.)

The excellence of great forests and hills. (Text as in Zhang Wen’s edition: *"great forests."*)

Bathing the elders. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly rendered as *"rest."*)

Above: five characters
**Parables**

Like watching birds, sparrows, mosquitoes, and midges. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Urging the duke to die for his private ends. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Before, hair bound up—now, hair let loose. (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

How much more so for ghosts that depend on others? (Text as in Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Above: four characters
**Lie Yukou**

No excess, no surplus. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition and Zhang’s edition; formerly omitted.)

You manage yourself. (Pronounced *ji*; text as in the Jiangnan Li edition; formerly rendered as *"already."*)

Seal your mouth and taste its goodness. (Text as in Zhang Wen’s and Li’s editions; formerly rendered as *"Seal your beard and taste its goodness."*)

The utmost person of old relied on Heaven and not on humanity. (Text as in Zhang Wen’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Being cautious in haste yet attaining understanding. (Text as in the Jiangnan ancient manuscript; formerly rendered as *"following."*)

Virtue and righteousness, much reproach—the six relations thus punish one another. Those distant from the nature of life are mere puppets. (Text as in Liu Deyi’s edition; formerly omitted.)

Above: twelve characters
**Under Heaven**

And the Nine Purifications cleanse the rivers under Heaven. (Text as in the Jiangnan Li edition; formerly rendered as *"miscellaneous."*)

Though not yet reaching the ultimate, (Text as in the Jiangnan Li and Wen editions; formerly rendered as *"may be called reaching the ultimate."*)

Above: three characters.

**Thirty-three chapters** contain omissions and errors, or dual interpretations, totaling three hundred forty-nine characters.

*Survey of Editions of the* True Scripture of Nanhua

In the fourth year of Jingde, the Directorate of Education edition; the Jiangnan ancient manuscript, collated by Xu Xuan and Ge Huan; the Tiantai Mountain Fangying Palace edition, collated by Xu Lingfu; the *Exegesis* by Cheng Yuanying, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Rectifying the Meaning* by Wen Ruhai, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Annotations* by Guo Xiang, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Annotations* by the layman Liu Deyi, from the Dazhong Xiangfu era.

The Jiangnan Li family library edition, supplemented with notes by Zhang Qianfu.

Above: nine editions, each with omissions, errors, and variant readings, yet each bearing its own significance.

*Concluding the Chapter and Verse Matters of the* True Scripture of Nanhua.

chunks.original_text: 南华真经章句余事 经名：南华真经章句余事。 北宋陈景元撰。 一卷。 底本出处：《正纯道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 南华真经章句余事 碧虚子造 分章篇巨 庄子内篇七 内篇逍遥游七章 顺化逍遥　极变逍遥　无已逍遥 无功逍遥　无为逍遥　适物逍遥 内篇齐物论十章 齐我　齐智　齐是非 齐道　齐治　齐物 齐死生　　齐同异　　齐因　齐化 内篇养生主五章 养性分　　得生理　　遗刑累 远樊笼　　释悬解 内篇人间世八章 化导　　　命使　　师传 不材恶名　神不矜能　材致不祥　疏德养身　有用致患 内篇德充符六章 鉴道　游内　务全 德平　德忘　无情 内篇大宗师十章 真人行　　不遁化　得道妙 才道相胥　死生友　相忘友 无情死　　游道域　坐忘　推极委命 内篇应帝王七章 不言之教　无为之治　自然之化 圣人无名　圣人无常心　寄托　开兑， 庄子外篇七 外篇骈拇一章

chunks.original_text: 乐生　规葬， 杂篇天下七章 儒道　墨教　明治 论法　替老　叙庄 评惠 右三十三篇共二百五十五章 阙误 逍遥游 亦若是而已矣见文如海本，旧作则。 枪榆枋而止见文本及江南本，旧阙。 腹犹颗然见文本，旧作果。 彼之二虫又何知也见文本，旧阙。 八千岁为秋此大年也见成元英本，旧阙。 岂唯形骸有聋瞽哉见天台山方瀛观古藏本，旧作盲。 请买其方以百金见江南古藏本，旧阙。 安所困苦哉文作安所穷困哉。 右十三字 齐物论 老洫江南古藏本作溢。 虽我亦成也江南古藏本作虽我无成，亦可谓成矣。 仁常而不周见江南古藏本，旧作成。 飘风振海见江南李氏本，旧阙。 圣人愚芼见刘得一本，旧作芚。 则是之异乎不是也，其无辩矣。 然若果然也则然之异乎不然也，亦无辩矣。 见江南古藏本。 右十二字

chunks.original_text: 养生主 牛不知其死也，如土委地。 见文如海刘得一本； 旧阙。 始也吾以为至人也见文本，旧作其。 右七字 人间世 思其所行则庶几见李氏本，旧阙。 曰嘻若往而殆刑耳见张君房本，旧作若殆往而刑耳。 衒暴人之前者见江南古藏本，旧作术。 有心而为之其易邪见张本，旧阙。 寡不道以欢成江南古藏本，作寡有不道以成欢。 其大蔽数千牛文成李张本同，旧阙。 将隐芘其所赖见张本，旧作隐将。 却曲却曲见张本，旧作吾行却曲。 右二十字 德充符 守其宗者也见江南古藏本，旧阙。 受命於地，唯松栢独也。 正在冬夏青青受命於天，唯尧舜独也。 正在万物之首，见张本，旧阙，计子之德口足以自反邪？ 文成李张同，旧作不足以自反邪。 不知先生之洗我以善邪，吾之自寤邪，见张本旧阙孔丘之於至人口未邪？ 见张本，旧作其未邪。 右十四字 大宗师 邴邴乎其似喜乎，崔乎，其不得已乎，厉乎，其似世乎？ 文成张作邴邴乎其似喜也，崔崔乎其不得已也，厉乎其似世也。 善少见张本，旧作夭。 故杀生者不死见江南古藏本，旧阙。 往侍事焉见张本，旧作待。 右七字

chunks.original_text: 应帝王 庶民孰敢不听而化诸见张本，旧作度人。 吾与汝无其文见江南古藏本，旧作既。 不震不止见江南古藏本，旧作正。 纷然而封哉见张本，旧阙。 右五字 骈拇 而多方於聪明之用也张作而多口於聪明之用也。 而枝者不为岐见江南古藏本，旧作跂。 右二字 马□ 络之见江南古藏本，旧作雒。 右一字 胠筐 曷尝不法圣智哉？ 善人不得圣智之道不立，跖不得圣智之道不行，则圣智之利天下也少。 圣智生而大盗起，掊击圣智，圣智已死。 圣智不死，虽重圣智，是乃圣智之过也。 彼圣智者，天下之利器也。 并见张本，旧作人。 右十一字 刻意

chunks.original_text: 故曰：圣人休焉，休则平易矣。 见张本，旧作圣人休休焉，则早易矣。 右一字 缮性 缮性於俗口学以求复其初见张本，旧作缮性於俗，俗学以求复其初。 滑欲於欲思以求致其明见张本，旧作俗。 古之治道者，以恬养智，智生而无以智为也，谓之以智养恬见张本，旧阙。 义明而物亲忠也见江南古藏本，作中。 礼乐徧行江南古藏本，作偏。 四时应节见张本，旧作得。 又何为乎哉见张本，旧阙。 轩冕在身非性命之有也见张本，旧阙。 右九字 说剑 悝当何敢言见张本，旧作尚。 右一字 渔父 皎白见张本，旧作交。 侍於下风见张本，旧作待。 以败德人见张本，旧作恶者，乌路切。 右三字 禅王

chunks.original_text: 恐听口谬见张本，旧作恐听者谬。 弦歌见张本，旧阙。 不以羡自累也见李氏本，旧作利。 神无恶也见张本，旧作乎。 吾是以知松栢之茂也，桓公得之莒齐子纣之乱，小白出奔莒。 文公得之曹曹人观晋公子骿胁。 越王得之会稽越为吴败，勾践以败，卒保於会稽山。 陈蔡之隘於丘其幸乎自桓公并注至会稽山，四十八字，见江南古藏本，旧阙。 故许由虞於颖阳而共伯得志乎丘首虞，安也。 见江南古藏本，旧作误志，旧阙。 殷德衰见江南古藏本，旧作周。 右五十五字 盗跖 穴室抠户见刘得一本，旧作枢。 休卒徒於太山之阳见江南古藏本，旧阙。 凡天下人有三德见张本，旧阙。 此七子者世之所高也见江南古藏本，旧作六。 此六子者无异於磔犬流豕见江南古藏本，旧作四。 操瓢而乞者皆利名轻死见张本，旧作离。 汝行如桀纣则口作色有不服之心者见张本，旧作则有怍色。 吾昔与子讼於无约曰见张本，旧作曰。 则亦犹夕病长阨见江南古藏本，旧阙。 若负重行而上坂也见张本，旧阙。 贪财而取辱见张本，旧作慰。 右十一字 在宥 空同之山见张本，旧作上。 以此因人之国侥幸也见江南古藏本，旧阙。 右二字 天地

chunks.original_text: 故通於天者，道也； 顺於地者，德也。 行於万物者，义也。 见江南古藏本，旧阙上五字，义作道。 沈珠於渊见张本，旧作藏。 退己音纪，见江南古藏本，旧作巳。 有机械於此其名桔槔并见张本机，旧阙，桔旧作为。 圣人所羞也见张本，旧作圣人羞之。 不相罪坐见张本，旧阙。 右十三字 天道 其自然为也见张本，旧阙。 而道德之至也见张本，旧阙。 实者伦矣江南古藏本，作实者备矣。 刑名比详见张本下同，旧作刑。 夫天地至神矣见张本，旧阙。 安取道哉见文本，旧阙。 非知治之道者也见江南古藏本，旧阙。 渊渊乎其不可测也见江南古藏本，旧阙。 右九字 天运

chunks.original_text: 孰隆施是李氏作弛。 在上彷徨见张本，旧作有。 名者公器也见张本，旧阙。 又奚杰杰然见张本，旧阙。 予口张而不能胁舌举而不能初见江南古藏本，旧阙。 然则至人见江南古藏本，旧阙。 发动如天地者哉见张 本，旧作乎。 三皇五帝之治天下也。 昔黄帝之治天下见江南古藏本，旧阙。 眸子不运而感风化雌应於下风而感风化故曰风化并见张本，旧阙。 右十七字 秋水 五帝之所运见江南古藏本，旧作连。 故异便耳见张本，旧阙。 是故大人之行不出害人之涂也见张本，旧阙。 谓之篡之夫见张本，旧阙。 知乎人之行见江南古藏本，旧作天。 而不遇时也见江南古藏本，旧作得。 当尧舜之时当桀纣之时并见张本，旧阙。 出跳乎井干之上见江南古藏本，旧作跳梁。 且子曰见张本，旧阙。 右十四字 至乐

chunks.original_text: 吾未知之乐也，亦未知之不乐也，果有乐无有哉？ 吾以无为而诚者为乐矣。 并见江南古藏本，旧阙。 万物皆化生见江南古藏本，旧阙。 今有变之而死见江南古藏本，旧作今又变而之死。 髑髅见梦曰向子之谈者见张本，旧阙。 泛然以天地为春秋见张本，旧作从。 而复为生人之劳乎见张本，旧作人间之劳乎。 彼必相与异其好恶好恶异故先圣不一其能见江南古藏本，旧作故异也。 种有几若谊为鹑见刘得一本，旧阙。 斯弥为食酰，食酰生乎颐辂，颐辂生乎黄軏，黄軓生乎九猷，九猷生乎瞀芮，瞀芮生乎腐蠸，腐蠸生乎羊奚，羊奚比乎不筍，久竹生青宁并见张本，旧阙。 右三十八字 达生 是形色而已见江南古藏本，旧阙。 物焉得而正焉见张本，旧作止。 不开人之人见刘得一本，旧作天。 以瓦殶钩殶金殶见吕览，旧作注。 有张毅者见高门县簿见刘得一本，旧阙。 人之所最畏者见江南古藏本，旧作取。 吾将三月豢汝见张本，旧作，篇韵不收。 自为谋则取之其所异彘者何也见张潜夫本，旧阙。 异鸡无敢应见者反走矣文如海刘得一同，旧阙。 其由是与见江南古臧本，旧阙。 口忘是非张文本同，旧作知忘是非。 则安平陆而已见刘得一本，旧阙。 右一十四字 山木

chunks.original_text: 运化之泄也见江南古藏本，旧作物。 蹇裳躩步见张本，旧作蹇。 庄子反入宫三月不庭见江南古藏本，旧阙。 从其令江南李氏成本同，旧作俗。 口口虞人以吾为戮张文本同，旧作栗林虞人。 逆旅之有妾二人见刘得一本，旧作人。 右七字 田子方 其导我也似父见江南古藏本，旧作道。 右一字 知北游 知如字，旧音智不取。 故曰通天地之一气耳见刘得一本，旧作通天下一气。 合彼神明至精见刘得一本，旧作令。 子孙非汝有见张本，旧作孙子。 运量万物而不遗文刘本同，旧作匮。 汝唯莫必谓无乎逃物张成本同，旧阙。 山林与皋壤与与我无亲使我欣欣然而乐与见江南藏本，旧阙。 右十一字智字在外 庚桑楚

chunks.original_text: 辞尽矣口奔蜂不能化藿烛江南李氏张本同，旧作曰，奔蜂不能化藿烛。 十日息愁江南李氏文刘张同，旧、作自。 人见其人物见其物见张本，旧阙。 每妄更为失见刘得一本，旧 阙。 出入而不见其形见张本，旧作入出。 孰知有无死生之一宗者见文本，旧作守。 又适其偃溲焉江南李氏张本同，旧阙。 移是非今之人也江南李氏张本同，旧阙。 右十二字 徐无鬼 藜藿柱宇鼪鼬之径文张同，旧作乎。 察士无陵谇之辞则不乐见文成张本同，旧作凌谇之事。 听而斲之暝目恣手尽垩而鼻不伤见江南李氏本，旧四字是郭注。 可不讳云见江南李氏本，旧作谓。 游於天地也见江南古藏本，旧阙。 择疏鬣长毛自以为广宫大囿见张本，旧阙。 古之真人以天待人见张本，旧作之。 右十二字 则阳 同槛而浴见张本，旧作滥。 气之广者也见刘得一本，旧作大。 右二字 外物

chunks.original_text: 我且南游说吴越之王见张本，旧阙。 出拾薪见张本，旧阙。 中民之行易进焉耳张成本同，旧阙。 大林丘山之善张文本作大林。 沐老见张本，旧作休。 右五字 寓言 如观乌雀蚊见张本，旧阙。 劝公以其私死也见张本，旧阙。 向也括撮而今也被发见张本，旧阙。 而况乎以鬼有待者乎见张本，旧阙。 右四字 列御寇 旡多余之赢江南李氏张本同，旧阙。 汝处己音纪，江南李氏本旧作巳。 阖口尝视其良文成李氏同，旧作阖胡尝视其良。 古之至人天而不人见张文本，旧阙。 有慎懁而达见江南古藏本，旧作顺。 仁义多责六者所以相刑也远生之情者傀见刘得一本，旧阙。 右十二字 天下

chunks.original_text: 而九涤天下之川江南李氏本，旧作杂。 虽未至极江南李氏文本同，旧作可谓至极。 右三字 右三十三篇阙误，或两义，共三百四十九字。 览过南华真经名氏 景德四年，国子监本江南古藏本，徐铉葛湍校天台山方瀛宫藏本，徐灵府校成元英解疏中太一宫本，张君房校文如海正义中太一宫本，张君房校郭象注中太一宫本，张君房校散人刘得一注大中祥符时人。 江南李氏书库本，张潜夫补注。 右九家阙误同异，各有义旨。 南华真经章句余事竟

*Survey of Editions of the* True Scripture of Nanhua

In the fourth year of Jingde, the Directorate of Education edition; the Jiangnan ancient manuscript, collated by Xu Xuan and Ge Huan; the Tiantai Mountain Fangying Palace edition, collated by Xu Lingfu; the *Exegesis* by Cheng Yuanying, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Rectifying the Meaning* by Wen Ruhai, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Annotations* by Guo Xiang, from the Central Taiyi Palace edition, collated by Zhang Junfang; the *Annotations* by the layman Liu Deyi, from the Dazhong Xiangfu era.

The Jiangnan Li family library edition, supplemented with notes by Zhang Qianfu.

Above: nine editions, each with omissions, errors, and variant readings, yet each bearing its own significance.

*Concluding the Chapter and Verse Matters of the* True Scripture of Nanhua.
